channel.title: Blind Embossing on Ric - An unknown artist
channel.description: Recent content in Blind Embossing on Ric - An unknown artist

item.title: Wikipedia article on "Kunstverlag J.C. Blumenberg"
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
There is now a Wikipedia Article on the “Kunstverlag J.C. Blumenberg” , the publisher where many prints of Fritz Neumann and his wife published their works, in the German Wikipedia. It also includes images of the blind stamp to enable easier recognition (e.g. via Google Lens).

Thanks to all contributors for their help!

item.title: Fritz Neumann etching of a yacht anchored near a shoreline
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short description: A colourised etching of a yacht anchored near a shoreline by Fritz Neumann.

Notes:

  • Found on ebay

item.title: Fritz Neumann Etching of Cutter Boats
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short description: A colourised etching of cutter boats in by Fritz Neumann. Send in by Rainer Lilje-Halbritter.

Notes: This print is also part of the Collection of watercolours paintings .

item.title: Fritz Neumann Lake

item.description:
Short description: A colourised etching of a lake by Fritz Neumann. The post shows two identical prints.

Notes:

  • Found on eBay

item.title: Hedwig Klinge Magnolias
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short description: A etching of Magnolias by Hedwig Klinge, wife of Fritz Neumann.

Notes: Thanks to Mark Strong of Meibohm Fine Arts for providing the image. Note, that the JCB blind embossing is clearly visible.

Images by Mark Strong of Meibohm Fine Arts .

item.title: An unknown etching of a flamingo by Fritz Neumann
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short description: Coloured etching of a flamingo by Fritz Neumann

Notes: Found on in an antiquarian bookshop in Hannover. The embossed mark of J.C. Blumenberg is clearly recognisable. Matching the title of the newspaper article on Fritz Neumann .

item.title: An unknown etching by Fritz Neumann
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short description: Coloured etching of a duck pond by Fritz Neumann

Notes: Found on a flea market (Flohmarkt Flohschanze) in Hamburg. The embossed mark of J.C. Blumenberg is clearly recognisable.

item.title: Another version of the "JCB" blind stamp
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
This is the probably older version of the blind stamp that’s used on some prints by Fritz Neumann.

It imitates the Holsten Gate in Lübeck (second image), another indication of a North German origin. So far, inquiries from the Lübeck City Archives about former art publishers in the city have not yet been answered.

item.title: A dachshund (Fritz Neumann)
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short description: A dachshund

Notes: Taken from Cofart.be . The stamp mark is clearly visible.

item.title: Two dogs - fox terrier (Fritz Neumann)
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short description: Two dogs, fox terrier.

Notes: Taken from eBay . This one is quite interesting, it’s attributed to Hermann Fritz Neumann and should be quite old. It also features the stamp mark, but in another form: The letters “J”, “C” and “B” are not overlapping, and are put in the middle of the Holstentor .

item.title: Sailing boats in a harbour (Fritz Neumann)
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
Short Description: Sailing boats in a harbour / near a shore

Notes: Another maritime subject by Fritz Neumann, on the back is a sticker reading “Echt Aquarell” (Original aquarelle). But this is clearly a colourised print, since there is a platemark.

item.title: This is the stamp mark used on the prints of Ric
item.author: mail@christianmahnke.de (Christian Mahnke)
item.description:
This is the stamp mark (blind stamp) used on the prints of Ric and Fritz Neumann. There is now a dedicated page on this trace. It will be updated in the next few days with more examples and traces.

You can also look at the pages tagged with “Blind embossing” .
